metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: The JavaScript this Keyword

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  id       : 5566,
  fullName : function() {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
};

content.text: What is this ?
In JavaScript, the this keyword refers to an object .
content.html: In JavaScript, the this keyword refers to an object.

content.text: The this keyword refers to different objects depending on how it is used:
content.html: The this keyword refers to different objects depending on how it is used:

content.text: Note
this is not a variable. It is a keyword. You cannot change the value of this .
content.html: this is not a variable. It is a keyword. You cannot change the value of this.

content.text: this in a Method
When used in an object method, this refers to the object .
content.html: When used in an object method, this refers to the object.

content.text: In the example on top of this page, this refers to the person object.
content.html: In the example on top of this page, this refers to the person object.

content.text: Because the fullName method is a method of the person object.
content.html: Because the fullName method is a method of the person object.

content.code_html:
fullName : function() {
  return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
}

content.text: this Alone
When used alone, this refers to the global object .
content.html: When used alone, this refers to the global object.

content.text: Because this is running in the global scope.
content.html: Because this is running in the global scope.

content.text: In a browser window the global object is [object Window] :
content.html: In a browser window the global object is [object Window]:

content.code_html: let x = this;

content.text: In strict mode , when used alone, this also refers to the global object :
content.html: In strict mode, when used alone, this also refers to the global object:

content.code_html:
"use strict";
let x = this;

content.text: this in a Function (Default)
In a function, the global object is the default binding for this .
content.html: In a function, the global object is the default binding for this.

content.text: In a browser window the global object is [object Window] :
content.html: In a browser window the global object is [object Window]:

content.code_html:
function myFunction() {
  return this;
}

content.text: this in a Function (Strict)
JavaScript strict mode does not allow default binding.
content.html: JavaScript strict mode does not allow default binding.

content.text: So, when used in a function, in strict mode, this is undefined .
content.html: So, when used in a function, in strict mode, this is undefined.

content.code_html:
"use strict";
function myFunction() {
  return this;
}

content.text: this in Event Handlers
In HTML event handlers, this refers to the HTML element that received the event:
content.html: In HTML event handlers, this refers to the HTML element that received the event:

content.code_html:
<button onclick="this.style.display='none'">
  Click to Remove Me!
</button>

content.text: Object Method Binding
In these examples, this is the person object :
content.html: In these examples, this is the person object:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName  : "John",
  lastName   : "Doe",
  id         : 5566,
  myFunction : function() {
    return this;
  }
};

const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  id       : 5566,
  fullName : function() {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
};

content.text: i.e. this.firstName is the firstName property of this (the person object).
content.html: i.e. this.firstName is the firstName property of this (the person object).

content.text: Explicit Function Binding
The call() and apply() methods are predefined JavaScript methods.
content.html: The call() and apply() methods are predefined JavaScript methods.

content.text: They can both be used to call an object method with another object as argument.
content.html: They can both be used to call an object method with another object as argument.

content.text: See Also:
The Function call() Method
content.html: The Function call() Method

content.text: The Function apply() Method
content.html: The Function apply() Method

content.text: The Function bind() Method
content.html: The Function bind() Method

content.text: The example below calls person1.fullName with person2 as an argument, this refers to person2, even if fullName is a method of person1:
content.html: The example below calls person1.fullName with person2 as an argument, this refers to person2, even if fullName is a method of person1:

content.code_html:
const person1 = {
  fullName: function() {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
}

const person2 = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName: "Doe",
}

// Return "John Doe":
 person1.fullName.call(person2);

content.text: Function Borrowing
With the bind() method, an object can borrow a method from another object.
content.html: With the bind() method, an object can borrow a method from another object.

content.text: This example creates 2 objects (person and member).
content.html: This example creates 2 objects (person and member).

content.text: The member object borrows the fullname method from the person object:
content.html: The member object borrows the fullname method from the person object:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  fullName: function () {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
}

const member = {
  firstName:"Hege",
  lastName: "Nilsen",
}

let fullName = person.fullName.bind(member);

content.text: This Precedence
To determine which object this refers to; use the following precedence of order.
content.html: To determine which object this refers to; use the following precedence of order.

content.text: Is this in a function being called using bind()?
content.html: Is this in a function being called using bind()?

content.text: Is this in a function being called using apply()?
content.html: Is this in a function being called using apply()?

content.text: Is this in a function being called using call()?
content.html: Is this in a function being called using call()?

content.text: Is this in an object function (method)?
content.html: Is this in an object function (method)?

content.text: Is this in a function in the global scope.
content.html: Is this in a function in the global scope.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
True or False. You cannot change the value of this .
content.html:
True or False.
You cannot change the value of this.
